sub_topic: Calculation of the electrical conductivity of a metal
message_1: What is the electrical conductivity (in Siemens/meter) of a metal wire consisting of 2.5 x 10^20 copper atoms per cubic meter with an average electron velocity of 1.5 x 10^6 m/s, a mean free path of 3.2 x 10^-8 meters and an electric field of 5 V/m?
message_2:
To find the electrical conductivity of the metal wire, we can use the Drude model of electrical conductivity. The Drude model formula for conductivity (σ) is:

σ = n * e^2 * τ / m

where n is the number of free electrons per unit volume, e is the elementary charge (1.6 x 10^-19 C), τ is the relaxation time, and m is the mass of an electron (9.11 x 10^-31 kg).

First, we need to find the relaxation time (τ). The relaxation time can be calculated using the mean free path (λ) and the average electron velocity (v) as follows:

τ = λ / v

Substituting the given values:

τ = (3.2 x 10^-8 m) / (1.5 x 10^6 m/s)
τ ≈ 2.13 x 10^-14 s

Now, we need to find the number of free electrons per unit volume (n). Copper has one free electron per atom, so the number of free electrons per unit volume is the same as the number of copper atoms per unit volume:

n = 2.5 x 10^20 electrons/m^3

Now we can calculate the electrical conductivity (σ) using the Drude model formula:

σ = (2.5 x 10^20 electrons/m^3) * (1.6 x 10^-19 C)^2 * (2.13 x 10^-14 s) / (9.11 x 10^-31 kg)
σ ≈ 1.45 x 10^7 Siemens/meter

So, the electrical conductivity of the metal wire is approximately 1.45 x 10^7 Siemens/meter.
